23 <s>13<\s> 
two skulls are preserved in the British Museum 
along with the one from Eschscholtz Bay. In the 
west of England two very well preserved fragments of the 
skulls of a male and female PlIII have been found by M<sup>r<\sup> 
Charles Moore in the gravels of the Avon at Freshford 
near Bath 1. The remains of other animals which I have 
seen from the same place belong to the Mammoth, Bison 
Horse and Reindeer. In 1866 I examined the locality 
along with the Rev<sup>d<\sup> H.H. Winwood F.G.S. In the narrow 
valley which the river Avon has cut trough the Bath 
and Inferior oolites into the inferior oolite sands are patches 
of gravel, above, at different heights. the present stream. The 
section exposed near the Freshford Railway Station from which the 
Musk Sheep were obtained presents a lenticular mass of gravel 
consisting of waterworn pebbles of Mountain Limestone, Flint 
Chert, Oolite, Hornstone, Quartzite, Old-Red-Sandstone and fossil shells 
from the subjacent beds resting on the Inferior oolite <s>sands<\s> limestone 
at the bottom are a few big boulders and the pebbles are 
larger there than n the upper or middle part. The whole 
bed is highly confused and presents none of the sorting action 
which would be the result of pebbles transported by a 
river flowing under temperate conditions. It could indeed 
only have been deposited by an ice burdened river under 
severe climatal conditions. [insertion] The list of animals derived 
from it leads to the same conclusion, for two out of the 
five, the Reindeer and the Musk Sheep, are found now only 
under an arctic climate and all the species occur in 
the frozen cliff in Eschscholtz Bay. I have not the slightest 
doubt but that the fluviatile ossiferous deposits <s>resting on 
the solid ice<\s> in both these localities, were formed under
